title: Planning and designing a shelterbelt - lessons learnt from the Pinery fire

tasks.task: Planting and managing shelter belts and windbreaks for agricultural benefits.
subtasks: Ripping land a year in advance of planting to improve soil moisture and root development.
Ordering native plants, tree guards, and stakes well in advance (at least a year before planting).
Choosing appropriate local tree species for the shelter belt based on their form and permeability.
Planting shelter belts at right angles to prevailing winds to optimize windbreak effectiveness.
Ensuring windbreaks have no gaps to prevent wind tunneling, which can increase wind speed and cause erosion.
Starting weed control measures a year before planting to prepare the land.
Planting shelter belts before the break of the season (April or Autumn) when soil is still warm for better root development.
Irrigating newly planted shelter belts until they become established (e.g., in February of the year following the fire).
Replanting areas affected by a fire (like in 2015's Pinery Fire) to restore windbreaks and native vegetation.
Monitoring and selecting surviving trees for their resilience to provide insights into effective shelter belt species.
Understanding and applying knowledge of how shelter belts and native vegetation affect fire behavior and wind patterns.

tasks.task: Establishing and maintaining shelter belts for biodiversity and habitat.
subtasks: Ensuring shelter belts include small shrubs in the outer rows and larger trees in the center for biodiversity and habitat.
Considering the permeability of shelter belts to allow wind flow while reducing speed and turbulence.
Protecting young trees in shelter belts with tree guards and stakes.
Providing supplemental water for new plantings to ensure survival and rapid establishment.
Maintaining shelter belts by removing weeds and managing tree health to preserve their structural integrity and benefits.

tasks.task: Evaluating the impact of shelter belts on agricultural productivity.
subtasks: Assessing the effect of shelter belts on crop yields near the windbreaks.
Measuring changes in evaporation rates due to shelter belts in adjacent paddocks.
Noting any changes in soil erosion in areas protected by shelter belts.
Observing the influence of shelter belts on wind speeds and turbulence in agricultural fields.

tasks.task: Planting trees in a way that enhances their benefits for animals, birds, and other wildlife.
subtasks: Selecting trees that provide shelter for livestock during extreme weather.
Choosing species that attract beneficial insects and birds that help control pests.
Planting trees that offer shade and contribute to a better microclimate for crops and farm infrastructure.
Designing shelter belts with species that form barriers to prevent pest movement and protect crops.
